metadata.sermon_start_end: And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives. (Mark 14:26) Some men sit in soft candlelight whose flicker rises and falls with each gust of wind blowing in from an open window. It is somebody's attic room, doubtless in one of the [...] At Calvary, there has begun a new fellowship. It is not confined to any one race, to any one section of the earth. It is the fellowship of all who have come to believe in the healing of the brokenhearted, in deliverance for the captives, in recovering of sight for the blind, in setting at liberty those that are bruised. This is the new fellowship begun by that cross.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Mark 14:26 as a springboard but quickly dissolves into generalities about 'the gospel' and 'Calvary'. It fails Dekker's test of finding what is in THIS passage that is nowhere else. Instead of a specific exposition of the hymn-singing or the movement to the Mount of Olives, it uses the text as a metaphor for the transition from private piety to social action.
quotes: That symbolizes what we would like our Christian discipleship to be all about.
There is a new principle of judgment thrown against the skyline of the centuries at Calvary.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus strictly on the specific act of singing a hymn in the face of death. What makes this specific hymn-singing unique compared to other biblical songs?

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Hebrew or Greek knowledge, nor of the specific religious history of the Passover Hallel. The 'exposition' is largely imaginative reconstruction of a 'candlelight' atmosphere rather than theological exegesis of the Marcan narrative.
quotes: It is somebody's attic room, doubtless in one of the humbler homes in an undistinguished back street...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the historical-theological significance of the Passover psalms (the Hallel) and the specific context of the Mount of Olives in Jewish messianic expectation.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding social justice and the American political context (Lyndon Johnson), which aligns with Dekker's demand for relevance to the zeitgeist. However, it risks becoming a 'speech about refugees/human rights' rather than an application of the specific text.
quotes: Should we defeat every enemy and should we double our wealth and conquer the stars and still be lacking on this issue of human rights, we will have failed as a people...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'going out' of the text more directly to the specific contemporary 'going out' into political conflict, rather than switching to general Calvary-theology.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves from a descriptive scene (exposition-lite) to a series of thematic reflections. The hearer is drawn into a mood, but the 'present of revelation' where the text itself speaks to the now is obscured by the preacher's narrative style.
quotes: Ah, there it is in brief compass. They sang a hymn... There was more to it than singing a hymn...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'first then' structure. Let the specific details of the text (the hymn, the mount) immediately expose the current situation of the congregation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present in the form of 'cataclysmic and terrifying evils' and 'human rebellion'. Redemption is linked to Calvary. However, the 'gratitude' part is replaced by a social-ethical 'new pattern of humanity'. The psychological depth Dekker seeks is present but leans toward sociology.
quotes: The chronicle is honest in declaring the craven cowardice and base desertion...
The timeless gospel of God's love and human rebellion...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' from social failure to the 'misery before God' as Dekker defines it.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes the 'lostness in time'â€”the collective failure of a nation. It presents a clear choice between the 'machinery of state' and the 'purposes of God'. It lacks the 'eternal loss' dimension but fulfills the 'temporal loss' aspect Dekker allows.
quotes: This nation with all its wealth and influence will live or die as it meets or fails to meet the purposes of God.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the individual responsibility of the hearer more sharply; the choice currently feels largely national/collective.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'telos', but the sermon leans heavily on Christ as an 'example' or a 'principle of judgment' rather than the ontological Savior (God-man). The doctrine of the two natures is not felt; Christ is more of a heroic figure in a 'brave fellowship'.
quotes: Jesus and his friends went out to establish a new pattern of humanity.
His deed at Calvary... makes the gospel startlingly relevant...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly ground the 'new principle of judgment' in the divinity of Christ to avoid moralism.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon would last about 13-14 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'. It is too short to be a sermon by his definition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic background to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity and its tendency to treat the Bible passage as a thematic hook rather than a specific, unique word of God. It lacks rigorous exegesis (Thesis 2) and fails the 20-minute length requirement (Thesis 8). While it successfully engages the zeitgeist and avoids 'general truths' by being politically concrete, it risks becoming a speech on social ethics rather than a specific exposition of Mark 14:26.
strengths: Concrete application to the American zeitgeist and political responsibility.
Strong sense of 'temporal loss' (Thesis 6) regarding the fate of a nation.
Effective use of psychological tension between the 'upper room' and the 'violence' outside.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) prevents necessary depth.
Lack of specific exegesis of the Greek text or historical context of the Passover.
The specific uniqueness of the text (what is here and nowhere else) is lost in general Calvary-theology.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This text functions more as a theological-political address than a sermon according to Dekker's strict formal definition. It lacks the exegetical 'breadth' and the specific 're-creation' of the written Word into a current proclamatory word based on the unique content of the pericope.
